Sad enough to choose, especially since both missions have enormous potential for groundbreaking insights.

Titan is a worthy candidate, no question, but his stable position does not bring with it the overwhelming urgency - it does not run away and is in relatively accessible surroundings.

Asteroids like Bennu on little eccentric tracks are already hard to reach and explore. Much more, this applies to comets on their highly elliptical orbits, like Comet 67P.

Near-Earth asteroids and comets offer, firstly, for the near future the chance for exploration and use by humans.
Second, both types of celestial bodies pose potential threats to the Earth, unlike Titan.

To know these dangers and with this knowledge to gain a profit for the planet earth, I consider it a priority for more important than the exploration of a distant moon.

Conclusion:
One should not have to choose, there is enough money in the system - once less to play war, not finance another pointless armament program and science could catapult mankind forward.

For me a mission to either Europa or Enceladus would be the priority.  It would need to be able to drill through the ice (the Tiger stripes on Enceladus are my preferred spot, because it is probably thin ice there) and then launch a submarine with sufficient power to light and move, film, sample and analyse and of course transmit all that data back via the lander and / or the orbiting mother ship. So yeah Titan is indeed fascinating and full of interesting resources for us in the future, but for Pete's sake let's give ourselves the best chance of finding life and go to the liquid water.

Dragonfly definitely has my vote. Considering the time scales involved in missions like this, I think the sooner we get out there the better - so I can see it before I die! I'm not ancient, but I'm not getting any younger. I've had hopes of seeing humans returning to the moon, and perhaps to mars, in my lifetime. The more of humanity's eyes that can be deployed on other worlds in our home system the better. I also think that, like the Curiosity rover did, this will enrapture and inspire generations of future scientists. While sampling a comet is certainly something we should do someday, I think in the interest of furthering scientific discussion, involvement, and advancement by earthlings, nothing compares to exploring another world.

Titan of course. It's my second favourite place in the solar system (so far!).

I do think a quad is a little asking-for-trouble, and wonder why they wouldn't go with a blimp instead. It could be powered, like a Zeppelin, for full 3d flight, and the RTG could provide heat to control altitude quite easily when passive lift is needed. It would be nothing like a blimp here in terms of volume, since the lift requirements would be minuscule. Backup lifting envelopes may even be an option. Perhaps there's even an easy way to extract H2 from methane in a compact reaction chamber, to provide unlimited lifting gas.

Slap on a small instrument package below that can be lowered a little and it could do everything the quad can, but continuously (the instrument package could be 'landed'). Actually, it could do more. It could fly high into the atmosphere for measurements, and, if they go all-out in engineering the sucka, could land on a methane lake.
In short, I pick Titan, but not with a quad.

I don't really like either one for the costs involved here. I don't feel there's a ton to learn from just flying around and taking pictures on Titan. I feel like exploring the makeup of the surface through rovers like Curiosity and Opportunity is more worth while for the kind of costs we're talking about. On the flip side I'm also not sure there's a ton to learn about advancing space travel or life from a measly 80g sample of a comet 20 years from now.
Don't get me wrong I think they are both interesting missions but could all that money go towards more meaningful research.

I wouldn't be disappointed with either decision. For some reason I have always though about what it would take to rendezvous with a comet or asteroid and bring a sample back to earth. I think you have to get it while the getting is good. Titan will always be there but opportunities to land on an asteroid don't come around every year. I say do the asteroid thing first and save the Titan thing for another mission.

as for that assumption that the drone would work as long as any two broken rotors are not on the same arm, I wonder how creative NASA could get using only four rotors in the two pairs on opposite corners and have one of the perpendicular arms use it's rotors to push and pull as needed to maintain balance.

Drones are sexy, and will invoke more public backing/interest. We only have 1 titan but many/endless amounts of comets/asteroids. That said, the asteroid is obviously the best for scientific research and should be a goal for scientists. However, I think a successful and ongoing titan mission would get nasa the support to hopefully get more funding in the near future, perhaps allowing for multiple simultaneous sample returns. In 5-10 years the availability of heavy lift vehicles will be up exponentially, allowing cheaper, larger payloads so we can investigate more and further out asteroids with larger dV for bigger and faster sample returns.

Personally, I want to see a drone on both titan/mars, a gas balloon in venus upper atmosphere and a submarine robot to the depths of europa, or perhaps just a lander and a single use submarine that would sink to the sea/ocean/water? floor, take samples, then float back up (to just under the ice top) and communicate its findings with the lander for relaying back to earth. In turn, this will give us more data for a future long term investigation in europas oceans.
